text:
•  Underground exploration diamond drilling, comprising 74 drill holes for 
 12,040 drill metres. 
 •  Surface RC exploration drilling comprising nine (9) drill holes for 1000 drill 
 metres. 
 Total project expenditure for the reporting period was $63.9 million of which $1.1 
 million was direct exploration expenditure. 
 INTRODUCTION 
 Mining Leases 80/179 – 80/183 form the Sally Malay nickel project area. 
 Location and Access 
 The Project leases are located approximately 240km south of Kununurra and 2 
 km west of the Great Northern Highway, in the East Kimberley district of 
 north Western Australia. Access is via the Great Northern Highway thence 
 pastoral and exploration tracks (Figures 1 and 2). 
 Tenure 
 The leases cover an area of 37 square kilometres in the Kimberley Mineral 
 Field in Western Australia. Combined reporting status for the Mining Leases 
 was granted by the Department of Minerals and Energy on 23rd March 1992.  
 The  leases  were  originally  granted  to  Australian  Anglo  American  Limited 
 (AAA)  on  the  16  June  1987.  In  1989  the  Normandy  Group  acquired  the 
 Australian  interests  of  AAA  and  assumed  management  of  the  Sally  Malay 
 Project.  
 SMM acquired the Project leases from Normandy in March 2001.

text:
juxtaposition by complex faulting. The Sally Malay project tenements are 
 situated in the Central Zone. 
 The Eastern Zone is confined to the west of the Halls Creek, Angelo 
 and Osmond Faults. The geology of the Eastern Zone is dominated by 
 metasediments of the Halls Creek Group, but also includes various 
 volcanics and intrusives. The eastern boundary is unconformably 
 overlain by Cambrian volcanics and sediments. 
 The Western Zone lies between the Greenvale and Springvale Faults, 
 and is dominated by granitic and gabbroic bodies intruding the Marboo 
 Formation. 
 The Central Zone is bounded by the Halls Creek, Angelo and Osmond 
 Faults to the east, and the Ramsay Range and Springvale Faults to the 
 west. The oldest and most dominant rock type of the Central Zone is 
 the Tickalara Metamorphics, a deformed sequence of interbedded 
 mafic metavolcanics and metasediments. They are intruded by 
 numerous felsic and layered mafic to ultramafic intrusions, which are 
 also deformed and metamorphosed to varying degrees.  
 The regional metamorphic grade within the Tickalara Metamorphics increases 
 from southwest to northeast, with granulite facies garnet-cordierite-sillimanite 
 paragneisses predominating within the Sally Malay Project area. The 
 depositional age of the Tickalara Metamorphics is 1870Ma. Geochronological 
 data and field relationships within the metamorphics indicate that the 
 emplacement of the mafic-ultramafic intrusions of the Central Zone occurred 
 in multiple phases from approximately 1860Ma to 1830Ma. The intrusions 
 straddle a series of metamorphic events, including a peak granulite facies event 
 at about 1852Ma.  
 A northeast trending Ni-Cu-Co-PGE-Cr metallogenic province is recognised 
 within the Central Zone. The province is spatially associated with the Highway 
 Shear, which traverses the Central Zone along the western margin of the Mabel 
 Downs Tonalite. Southeast of the Highway Shear, the older (pre-peak 
 metamorphic) layered mafic intrusions, including the Panton, Toby, 
 Springvale, Big Ben, West McIntosh and the Melon Patch group intrusives, are 
 typically of the PGE-Cr association.

text:
The  Australian  interests  of  AAA  were  acquired  by  the  Normandy  Poseidon 
 Group  in  1989.  Normandy  reviewed  the  project  and  undertook  further 
 feasibility studies. In 1992, Normandy completed further exploration including 
 additional diamond drilling (11 holes; 2894m), stream sediment geochemistry, 
 ground  based  EM,  assessment  of  multi-client  magnetic  data,  metallurgical 
 testwork, process water exploration, weather surveys, baseline flora and fauna 
 surveys,  baseline  water  sampling  and  anthropological  surveys.  Resource 
 modelling  estimated  the  existence  of  5.1  million  tonnes  of  Indicated  and 
 Inferred mineralisation grading 1.7% Ni, 0.7% Cu and 0.1% Co. 
 Normandy entered into two unsuccessful agreements to sell the project during 
 the latter part of the nineties, during which time little further exploration was 
 undertaken on the Project leases. Sally Malay Mining Ltd acquired the project

 Project  Feasibility  Study  programme,  an  in-fill  drill  programme,  involving  a 
 total of 40 diamond and RC drill holes (SMD107 – 146, totalling 5770m). The 
 programme  had  the  broad  objective  to  further  delineate  the  Sally  Malay 
 resource and substantially improve the density of drill information ahead of a
